awd_titl_txt: Field, Laboratory, and Numerical Studies of Geyser Eruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Geysers provide a natural laboratory to study eruption processes and the geophysical and hydrological signals that can be measured before, during, and after an eruption. Because they are smaller than volcanic eruptions, and erupt more frequently, they provide a rare opportunity to collect abundant data and develop approaches for integrating and interpreting measurements.

About 3 million visitors to Yellowstone witness the wonders of geyser eruptions. Explanations for these phenomena, however, are limited or lacking. Geyser-like behavior of water and hydrocarbons has also been observed on the ocean floor and at mud volcanoes.  Thus improved understanding of geyser behavior may yield insight into other self-organized, intermittent processes in nature that result from localized input of energy and mass. Insights from studies of geysers can also be translated to volcanic systems. This project will integrate field measurements, laboratory studies, and numerical simulations of multiphase flow in geyser systems to address the following basic questions about the geysering process:  How does conduit plumbing affect eruption initiation and interval? Do eruptions begin at the top or bottom of the conduit? How many conduit volumes erupt per eruption? Do non-condensable gases play a role in eruptions? Which external processes (e.g., tides, variations in barometric pressure, earthquakes) and internal dynamics (e.g., duration of preceding eruption) influence the interval between and duration of eruption? How are geyser conduits recharged? When and where does vapor form? Answers to this question may offer new insight into triggered seismicity and volcanic eruptions.

por.por_cntn:
Geysers provide a natural laboratory to study eruption processes and the geophysical and hydrological signals that can be measured before, during, and after an eruption. Because they are smaller than volcanic eruptions, and erupt more frequently, they provide a rare opportunity to collect abundant data and develop approaches for integrating and interpreting measurements. Geysers also provide a window into key processes that occur in geothermal systems. More than 3 million visitors to Yellowstone witness the wonders of geyser eruptions. Explanations for these phenomena, however, were limited or lacking.

 

We used a combination of field studies, laboratory experiments, and numerical simulations of multiphase flow in geyser systems to answer the following basic questions about the geysering process:  Why are geysers uncommon? How does conduit plumbing affect eruption initiation and the time between eruptions? Do eruptions begin at the top or bottom of the conduit? How many conduit volumes erupt per eruption? Do non-condensable gases play a role in eruptions? Which external processes (e.g., tides, variations in barometric pressure, earthquakes) and internal dynamics (e.g., duration of preceding eruption) influence the interval between and duration of eruption?

 

A set of expeditions to the El Tatio geyser field, Atacama Desert, Chile and Lone Star geyser, Yellowstone provided a broad suite of measurements that allowed us to answer these questions. We showed that underground cavities allow steam to accumulate and that the episodic release of this steam initiates eruptions. The rarity of geysers reflects the unusual geology needed to create cavities. Once the eruption begins, boiling conditions propagate downward and eruptions end with the influx of colder groundwater. We showed that only geysers with large surface pools are sensitive to external conditions and developed a model to explain how geysers respond to external perturbations and how geysers interact with each other. Our measurements also allowed us to determine the mass and energy budget for the geothermal systems in Yellowstone and Chile. Field measurements from Geyser Valley, Kamchatka, allowed us to show that pressures are not greatly elevated in the hydrothermal systems that supply water to geysers, minimizing the risk of hydrothermal explosions.

 

This project provided full training for one PhD student, and several other graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral researchers were supported and involved in the research. Results were disseminated in scientific publications, a review paper, the popular press, and distributed to the native communities that manage the geysers in Chile.
